member.name: M:Unigine.Math.bezier(float,float,float)
member.summary: Calculates the value of a cubic Bezier function for t = time. A cubic Bezier curve is represented by 4 points. Po is the start point, P1 and P2 are control points 1 and 2 and P3 is the end point. The start and end point denote the beginning and end points of the path and the control points determine how the path moves from the start to the finish. As can be seen from the image, the only variable changing is t which determines how far the path has progressed from P0 to P3. Cubic Bezier curves are used as timing functions particularly for keyframe interpolation.
member.param: Coordinates of the four points of the curve along the horizontal T (times) axis in the range [0.0f, 1.0f].
Coordinates of the four points of the curve along the vertical V (values) axis in the range [0.0f, 1.0f].
Time in the range [0, 1], for which the value of the Bezier function is to be calculated.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.bezier(float,double,float)
member.summary: Calculates the value of a cubic Bezier function for t = time. A cubic Bezier curve is represented by 4 points. Po is the start point, P1 and P2 are control points 1 and 2 and P3 is the end point. The start and end point denote the beginning and end points of the path and the control points determine how the path moves from the start to the finish. As can be seen from the image, the only variable changing is t which determines how far the path has progressed from P0 to P3. Cubic Bezier curves are used as timing functions particularly for keyframe interpolation.
member.param: Coordinates of the four points of the curve along the horizontal T (times) axis in the range [0.0f, 1.0f].
Coordinates of the four points of the curve along the vertical V (values) axis in the range [0.0f, 1.0f].
Time in the range [0, 1], for which the value of the Bezier function is to be calculated.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.distance2(Unigine.vec2,Unigine.vec2)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between the two given vectors. The squared distance is calculated as: length2(v0 - v1). This method is much faster than distance() - the calculation is basically the same only without the slow Sqrt call. If you simply want to compare distances, then it is faster to compare squared distances against the squares of distances as the comparison gives the same result.
member.returns: Squared distance between the two given vectors.

member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between the two given vectors. The squared distance is calculated as: length2(v0 - v1). member.returns: Squared distance between the two given vectors.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.getAngle(Unigine.quat,Unigine.quat)
member.summary: Returns the angle (in degrees) between the given first and second quaternions. The angle returned is the unsigned acute angle between the two quaternions. This means the smaller of the two possible angles is used.
member.param: First quaternion (from which the angular difference is measured).
Second quaternion (to which the angular difference is measured).
member.returns: Angle between the given quaternions, in degrees within the range [0.0; 180.0].

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.getAngle(Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3)
member.summary: Returns the angle (in degrees) between the given first and second vectors. The angle returned is the unsigned acute angle between the two vectors. This means the smaller of the two possible angles is used.
member.param: First vector (from which the angular difference is measured).
Second vector (to which the angular difference is measured).
member.returns: Angle between the given vectors, in degrees within the range [0.0; 180.0].

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.getAngle(Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3)
member.summary: Returns the signed angle (in degrees) between the given first and second vectors relative to the specified "up" vector.
member.param: First vector (from which the angular difference is measured).
Second vector (to which the angular difference is measured).
Up vector, around which the other two vectors are rotated.
member.returns: Angle between the given vectors, in degrees within the range [-180.0; 180.0].

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.gradient4(float,Unigine.vec4)
member.summary: Returns a gradient value for the specified argument using four key components. The gradient value is determined as follows: smoothstep() method.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.inverseLerp(float,float,float)
member.summary: Returns the value calculated according to the following formula: (v - v0) / (v1 - v0) clamped within 0.0f and 1.0f.
member.param: The value specifying the beginning of the interval.
The value specifying the ending of the interval.
The value within the specified interval.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.smoothstep(float)
member.summary: Returns a smooth Hermite interpolation between 0 and 1, if x is in the range [0, 1]. It is convenient for creating a sequence of transitions using smoothstep to interpolate each segment as an alternative to using more sophisticated or expensive interpolation techniques.
member.returns: One of the following values:0 if x is less than 0;1 if x is greater than 1;interpolated value between 0 and 1 if x is in the range [0, 1].

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.smoothstep(double)

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.smoothstep(float,float,float)
member.summary: Returns a smooth Hermite interpolation between 0 and 1, if x is in the range [edge0, edge1]. It is convenient for creating a sequence of transitions using smoothstep to interpolate each segment as an alternative to using more sophisticated or expensive interpolation techniques.
member.returns: One of the following values:0 if x is less than edge0;1 if x is greater than edge1;interpolated value between 0 and 1 if x is in the range [edge0, edge1].

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.smootherstep(double,double,double)
member.summary: Returns a smooth interpolation between 0 and 1 using a fifth-order polynomial function, if x is in the range [edge0, edge1]. It is convenient for creating a sequence of transitions using smoothstep to interpolate each segment as an alternative to using more sophisticated or expensive interpolation techniques.
member.returns: One of the following values:0 if x is less than edge0;1 if x is greater than edge1;interpolated value between 0 and 1 if x is in the range [edge0, edge1].

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.composeRotationXYZ(Unigine.vec3)
member.summary: Composes a rotation matrix from the corresponding Euler angles. The Euler angles are specified in the axis rotation sequence - XYZ. It is an order of the rings in the three-axis gimbal set: X axis used as the outer ring (independent ring), while Z axis as the inner one (its rotation depends on other 2 rings). When we talk about axes in UNIGINE we assume that: X axis points to the right giving us a pitch angle. Y axis points forward giving us a roll angle. Z axis points up giving us a yaw (heading) angle. Players have a different coordinate system: X axis points to the right giving us a pitch angle. Y axis points up giving us a yaw (heading) angle. Z axis points backward giving us a -roll angle.
member.param: Vector, containing Euler angles, in degrees - (yaw, roll, pitch).

When we talk about axes in UNIGINE we assume that: X axis points to the right giving us a pitch angle. Y axis points forward giving us a roll angle. Z axis points up giving us a yaw (heading) angle. Players have a different coordinate system: X axis points to the right giving us a pitch angle. Y axis points up giving us a yaw (heading) angle. Z axis points backward giving us a -roll angle.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.decomposeTransform(Unigine.mat4,Unigine.quat,Unigine.quat,Unigine.vec3)
member.summary: Decomposes a given transformation matrix into a dual quaternion (representing both translation and rotation) and a scale vector. The dual-quaternion model is an accurate, computationally efficient, robust, and flexible method of representing rigid transforms and it is used in skeletal animation. See a Wikipedia article on dual quaternions and a beginners guide to dual-quaternions for more information.
member.param: Quaternion representing a real part of the dual quaternion.
Quaternion representing a dual part of the dual quaternion.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.frustum(float,float,float,float,float,float)
member.summary: Returns perspective projection matrix: Coordinates of top, left, right, bottom are set relatively to center point of the znear plane. There are two different points (A and B) on the picture above. Since the top, left, right, bottom are coordinates relatively to the center point of the znear plane, coordinates of the A point should be A(left, bottom, znear). Coordinates of the B point are B(k * left, k * bottom, zfar), where k = zfar/znear.
member.param: Left coordinate of the near clipping plane relatively to the center.
Right coordinate of the near clipping plane relatively to the center.
Bottom coordinate of the near clipping plane relatively to the center.
Top coordinate of the near clipping plane relatively to the center.
Distance to the near depth clipping plane.
Distance to the farther depth clipping plane.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.inverse(Unigine.quat)
member.summary: Returns inverse of a quaternion. The inverse of a quaternion is a quaternion that if multiplied by the original would result in identity matrix: qq -1 = 1. If q = a + bi + cj + dk, then q-1 = a - bi - cj - dk

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.inverse4(Unigine.mat4)
member.summary: Inverts a matrix that consists of a 34 sub-matrix (upper left) and a translation vector. The last row of the matrix is ignored. Compared to the inverse() function, this one is a bit faster and, which is more important, more stable. A matrix suitable for such inversion looks like this: The function does the same as inverse (dmat4)

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.acos(float)
member.summary: Returns the arc cosine of the given argument - the angle in radians, whose cosine is equal to the argument. a == cos(acos(a)) for every value of a that is within acos()'s range.
member.returns: Arc cosine of the argument, in radians.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.acos(double)
member.summary: Returns the arc cosine of the given argument - the angle in radians, whose cosine is equal to the argument. a == cos(acos(a)) for every value of a that is within acos()'s range.
member.returns: Arc cosine of the argument, in radians.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.asin(float)
member.summary: Returns the arc sine of the given argument - the angle in radians, whose sine is equal to the argument. a == sin(asin(a)) for every value of a that is within asin()'s range.
member.returns: Arc sine of the argument, in radians.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.asin(double)
member.summary: Returns the arc sine of the given argument - the angle in radians, whose sine is equal to the argument. a == sin(asin(a)) for every value of a that is within asin()'s range.
member.returns: Arc sine of the argument, in radians.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.atan(float)
member.summary: Returns the arc tangent of the given argument - the angle in radians, whose tangent is equal to the argument. a == tan(atan(a)) for every value of a that is within atan()'s range.
member.returns: Arc tangent of the argument, in radians.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.atan(double)
member.summary: Returns the arc tangent of the given argument - the angle in radians, whose tangent is equal to the argument. a == tan(atan(a)) for every value of a that is within atan()'s range.
member.returns: Arc tangent of the argument, in radians.

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.atan2(float,float)
member.summary: Returns the arc tangent of two arguments (x and y). It is similar to calculating the arc tangent of y / x, except that the signs of both arguments are used to determine the quadrant of the result.
member.returns: Result in radians, which is between -PI and PI (inclusive).

member.name: M:Unigine.Math.atan2(double,double)
member.summary: Returns the arc tangent of two arguments (x and y). It is similar to calculating the arc tangent of y / x, except that the signs of both arguments are used to determine the quadrant of the result.
member.returns: Result in radians, which is between -PI and PI (inclusive).
